"According to Japanese lore, folding one thousand Origami cranes is truly a labor of love. Tradition holds that the bride who finishes this task, called SENBAZURU, before her wedding day will be richly rewarded with a good and happy marriage. Paying homage to the majestic crane, which mates for life and is said to live one thousand years, the bride ensures her own good fortune."
Linda Mihara, in an interview in B For Savvy Brides, 1998
Today, the tradition of 1,000 cranes has taken on a beautiful new interpretation: the cranes are arranged into a design or family crest, and then framed. This is then displayed at the wedding reception, and afterwards, hung in their new home for continued good luck.
Two cranes and wisteria
The bride and groom may also enlist the help of family and friends to complete the task of folding the cranes, adding even more good luck and well wishes.
His and hers family crests
Linda@Origamihara.com
